awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Pro-Active Networks from Degradable Acetals (PANDAs) via Thiol-ene Photopolymerization
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic polymers are typically resistant to degradation and far outlive the useful lifetime of the use for which they are designed - a problem that results in the accumulation of plastics in landfills and oceans.  Even upon degradation, the byproducts of plastics are sometimes toxic and serve no useful or active purpose in the environment.  The Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of NSF Chemistry Division supports the efforts of Professors Patton and Mavrodi at the University of Southern Mississippi to advance the design of degradable polymers.  Essential oil derivatives are used as primary building blocks of the polymers.  The materials are designed to undergo complete degradation under mild conditions resulting in regeneration of essential oils. Stemming from the broad-spectrum antimicrobial and antifungal activity observed for many essential oil constituents, these degradable materials are potentially useful for a range of pharmaceutical, biomedical, and agricultural applications. The researchers have established active outreach programs to local K-12 schools including the ?What is a Polymer? program (impacting > 500 students annually) and the ?Discover Nature? summer science camp. A new outreach initiative and collaboration with the local 3D (Dynamic Dyslexia Design) School is initiated.  ?Science Nights @ 3D? engage dyslexic students (and their families) with hands-on activities that require visual, kinesthetic, and auditory processing while introducing fundamental, grade appropriate science and math concepts.

The overarching goal of this project is the design, synthesis, and characterization of degradable polymer thermosets called "pro-active networks from degradable acetals (PANDAs)" via thiol-ene photopolymerization.  The approach is rooted in the design of multifunctional acyclic and cyclic acetal monomers derived from essential oil precursors that enable control over network chemistry and network structure for tunable degradation profiles.  PANDAs covalently incorporate aldehydes (e.g., vanillin, anisaldehyde, citronellal) and phenolic compounds (carvacrol, thymol) derived from essential oils directly into the polymer network via an acetal linkage - either as pendant groups (cyclic acetal) or as an integral part of the polymer backbone (acyclic acetal).  Exposure to conditions conducive to acetal degradation (e.g., change in humidity/pH) regenerates the essential oil building blocks.  Degradation profiles are determined to ascertain the erosion mechanism (surface vs. bulk) and aldehyde/phenol release kinetics, and to correlate degradation/release profiles with chemical and physical properties of the polymer network (e.g., hydrophobicity and crosslink density).  The project actively trains a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary research environment and engages local K-12 schools, in outreach.  This includes a collaboration with the local Dynamic Dyslexia Design (3D) School.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. Degradable polymeric materials are finding widespread use in applications ranging from drug delivery to environment friendly plastics. The primary outcome of this project was the development of synthetic methods for the synthesis of degradable polymer thermosets derived from aldehyde and ketone building blocks. In initial efforts, these synthetic methods were used to generate degradable polymer thermosets containing hydrolysable acetal linkages derived from p-anisaldehyde – an extract from star anise (Pimpinella anisum) seeds. Serving as polymeric “pro-antimicrobials”, these materials released p-anisaldehyde upon acetal hydrolysis to exert potent antimicrobial activity against a variety of clinically relevant pathogens with minimal cytotoxicity. Using combinations of benzaldehyde derivatives to construct degradable thermosets, the “pro-antimicrobial” concept was extended to explore synergism against Pseudomonas aeruginosa – a common opportunistic human pathogen. Further exploiting the chemistry of benzaldehyde-based acetals provided a new approach to synthesize poly(thioether acetal) thermosets that undergo rapid on-demand degradation when exposed to light, where thiols serve as polarity reversal catalysts to facilitate a radical β-scission mechanism that results in destruction of the polymer thermoset. Using this approach, we showed that poly(thioether acetal) networks synthesized via thiol–ene photopolymerization rapidly degrade to alkyl benzoate byproducts when triggered with light, transitioning from solid to liquid within seconds. The light-driven construction and destruction processes, accessible through distinct differences in kinetics, enable photopatterning, additive/subtractive manufacturing, and wavelength-selective applications.

              This project also exploited the chemistry of ketals for the design on degradable poly(β-thioether ester ketal) thermosets with tunable degradation profiles, where timescales for degradation were dictated by the structure of the ketal. The potential to recover and reuse the diketone degradation by-product to regenerate a new batch of diketal monomer for synthesis of additional thermoset materials was also demonstrated. Translation of this ketal chemistry into epoxy-amine thermosets provided materials with performance metrics (e.g., processability, mechanical strength, thermal stability) that are comparable to commercially sourced epoxy-amine resins. In contrast to the commercial resins, the ketal-based materials developed during this project provide chemical stability under normal operation conditions but are fully degradable under aqueous acidic conditions. We demonstrated the ability to fabricate high-performance carbon fiber composites using the ketal-based resin and the ability to recover pristine carbon fibers for reuse following hydrolysis of the polymer matrix.

Broader Impacts. This NSF award has provided the opportunity to train and educate 11 graduate students (45% women, 27% underrepresented minorities), 7 undergraduate students (43% women), and 4 summer REU students (50% women) in synthetic polymer chemistry and polymer characterization. Results from this project contributed to the production of 6 doctoral dissertations, 3 honors college theses, 7 peer-reviewed publications (with 1 featured on the journal cover), and 35 presentations and local, regional, and national conferences. Students supported by this award also engaged of our next-generation scientists and engineers via outreach activities aimed at K-12 grades.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Derek L Patton
